options.title: -b sourceaddr[#port]
options.description:
Set the source IP address of the query, which is useful on machines with
      multiple interfaces. The sourceaddr must be a valid
      address on one of the host's network interfaces, or "0.0.0.0" or
      "::". An optional port may be specified by appending
      "#<port>".

options.title: -c class
options.description:
Set the query class. The default is IN; other
      classes are HS for Hesiod records and
      CH for Chaosnet records.

options.title: -f file
options.description:
Batch mode: dig reads a list of lookup requests to
      process from the given file. Each line in the file
      should be organized in the same way they would be presented as queries to
      dig using the command-line interface.

options.title: -h
options.description: Display a brief summary of command line arguments and options.

options.title: -i
options.description:
Do reverse IPv6 lookups using the obsolete RFC 1886 IP6.INT domain, which
      is no longer in use. Obsolete bit string label queries (RFC 2874) are not
      attempted.

options.title: -k keyfile
-p port
options.description:
Send the query to a non-standard port on the server, instead of the
      default port 53. This option would be used to test a name server that has
      been configured to listen for queries on a non-standard port number.

options.title: -q name
options.description:
The domain name to query. This is useful to distinguish the
      name from other arguments.

options.title: -t type
options.description:
The resource record type to query. It can be any valid query type. If it
      is a resource record type supported in BIND 9, it can be given by the type
      mnemonic (such as NS or
      AAAA). The default query type is
      A, unless the -x option is
      supplied to indicate a reverse lookup. A zone transfer can be requested by
      specifying a type of AXFR. When an incremental
      zone transfer is required, set the type to
      IXFR=N. The incremental zone
      transfer will contain the changes made to the zone since the serial number
      in the zone's SOA record was N.
    All resource record types can be expressed as
        TYPEnn, where
        nn is the number of the type. If the resource
        record type is not supported in BIND 9, the result will be displayed as
        described in RFC 3597.

options.title: -u
options.description: Print query times in microseconds instead of milliseconds.

options.title: -v
options.description: Print the version number and exit.

options.title: -x addr
options.description:
Simplified reverse lookups, for mapping addresses to names. The
      addr is an IPv4 address in dotted-decimal notation,
      or a colon-delimited IPv6 address. When the -x is
      used, there is no need to provide the name,
      class and type arguments.
      dig automatically performs a lookup for a name
      like ‘94.2.0.192.in-addr.arpa’ and
      sets the query type and class to PTR and
      IN respectively. IPv6 addresses are looked up
      using nibble format under the IP6.ARPA domain (but see also the
      -i option).

options.title: -y [hmac:]keyname:secret
options.description:
Sign queries using TSIG with the given authentication key.
      keyname is the name of the key, and
      secret is the base64 encoded shared secret.
      hmac is the name of the key algorithm; valid choices
      are hmac-sha1,
      hmac-sha224, hmac-sha256,
      hmac-sha384, and
      hmac-sha512. If hmac is not
      specified, the default is hmac-sha256.
    NOTE: You should use the -k option and
        avoid the -y option, because with
        -y the shared secret is supplied as a command
        line argument in clear text. This may be visible in the output from
        ps(1) or in a history file maintained by
        the user's shell.
